B. DAKE and R. V. CHAUDHARI Chemical Engineering Division, National Chemical Laboratory, Poona 411 008 (India) (Received August 4, 1986; accepted November 10, 1986) In our previous paper on the carbonylation of ethanol in aqueous medium [I], it is reported that in contrast to the rhodium complex- catalysed carbonylation of methanol in acetic acid medium, the rate of carbonylation rises to a maximum with increasing catalyst concentration, and decreases with a further increase in catalyst concentration. The rate equation proposed by us earlier [1] is based on the data in the lower catalyst concentration region. The purpose of this letter is to present a generalised rate equation incorporating the data over the entire range of catalyst con- centrations. The following rate equation was found to represent the data (reported in [1]) satisfactorily: R _ feilAHE]0-828^]0-664 A- l+^A]3 (1) where -R^ = the rate of carbonylation, mol cm"3 s~1, [A] = the concentration of catalyst, mol cm"3, fei = the rate constant (cm3 mol"1)1-492 s~1, [B] = the concentration of HI, mol cm~3, [C] = the concentration of ethanol, mol cm"3, k^ = the inhibition constant, (cm3 mol"1)3. The values of fei and k^ are evaluated at different temperatures and are presented in Table 1. From the temperature dependence of these newly obtained constants, the activation energies for the rate and the inhibition constants were evaluated and found to be 19.20 and 1.21 kcal mol"1, respectively. Thus, the rate equation presented here is more generalised and incorporates the rate inhibition at higher catalyst concentrations. N.C.L.
